title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol, as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary of the Air Force, is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the direction of the Secretary of the Air Force. The Civil Air Patrol is administered by the Chief of Staff of the Air Force under the Secretary of the Air Force. The organization has approved organizational elements and a National Board of Directors appointed by the Secretary of the Air Force, consisting of general officers, senior civilian employees, and members from the volunteer Civil Air Patrol membership. The National Board of Directors of the Civil Air Patrol appoints key positions including a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General from the civilian volunteer membership. The chairman of the Board is the senior active duty Air Force officer, with appointed members not exceeding a minority. The Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General of the Civil Air Patrol report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the National Board of Directors. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. The appointment or assignment of members is not restricted by any laws or regulations. Prohibiting active duty members or civilian employees from managing non-Federal entities. Air Force members in Civil Air Patrol positions cannot receive additional compensation. Executive Director and National Board can utilize CAP employees and volunteers. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize Air Patrol employees and volunteer members to administer the Civil Air Patrol. Members and employees are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from related laws and regulations. The Civil Air Patrol is subject to various statutes and regulations governing the conduct of Federal employees. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are also subject to specific requirements and regulations related to the provision of appropriated funds to private, nonprofit organizations. The Civil Air Patrol's powers, including adopting a constitution, are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in the chapter. The Civil Air Patrol's powers are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. The Air Force has a role in management and may receive assistance from other agencies.
